title: UniSync: A Unified Framework for Audio-Visual Synchronization
author: Tao Feng (Guangdong Laboratory of Artificial Intelligence and Digital Economy), Yifan Xie (Guangdong Laboratory of Artificial Intelligence and Digital Economy), Xun Guan (Shenzhen International Graduate School, Tsinghua University), Jiyuan Song (Guangdong Laboratory of Artificial Intelligence and Digital Economy), Zhou Liu (Guangdong Laboratory of Artificial Intelligence and Digital Economy), Fei Ma (Guangdong Laboratory of Artificial Intelligence and Digital Economy), Fei Yu (Guangdong Laboratory of Artificial Intelligence and Digital Economy), ...
relevance_why: The paper presents a method that can enhance audio-visual synchronization, which can be helpful for Dr. Liu's work on audio generation and restoration, particularly in how visual cues influence audio processing.
background: Audio-visual synchronization aims to align audio signals with visual content, particularly important in applications like lip synchronization for talking faces in video.
contribution: UniSync introduces a novel framework utilizing embedding similarities across various audio and visual representations to improve synchronization quality.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often relied on limited audio-visual representations and inadequate sampling strategies, restricting their effectiveness.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves synchronization performance by integrating multiple representation types and enhancing the contrastive learning approach with a margin-based loss and cross-speaker samples.

key_innovation: The method's flexibility to process diverse audio and visual representations enables better synchronization across various contexts and improves overall performance.
real_world_impact: UniSync's enhancements in lip synchronization quality can significantly benefit applications like video conferencing, content creation, and AI-generated media by providing a more natural user experience.

new_terms.contrastive learning: **Contrastive learning** is a machine learning technique that learns representations by comparing and contrasting data samples, typically using pairs of similar and dissimilar examples to enhance feature discrimination.
